tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"weak and needy" (UDB)
David refers to himself as "your servant," that is, God's servant. AT: "save me, your servant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
This is an exaggeration. David does not literally cry out all day long. This emphasizes that he cries out continually. AT: "continually" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
David refers to himself as "your servant," that is, God's servant. AT: "Make me, your servant" or "Make me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

tn.ref: In the day of my trouble
tn.text: Here "day" represents a longer period of time. AT: "During my times of difficulty" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"I pray to you"
The writer is not acknowledging these other gods exist. He is referring to false gods that people from other nations worship. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "the nations" represent the people. AT: "The people from all nations" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "name" represents the whole person. AT: "They will honor you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"very good things that amaze me"
"you are the only God"

tn.ref: Teach me your ways, Yahweh. Then I will walk in your truth
tn.text: A person who obeys what God wants is spoken of as if he were walking on God's way or road. AT: "Teach me your truth, Yahweh. Then I will obey what you say" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Unite my heart to reverence you
tn.text: Here "heart" represents a person's thoughts, emotions, and motives. Asking God to cause a person to respect him completely is spoken of as if the person's heart were in many pieces and that God unites them together. AT: "Cause me to respect you sincerely with all my heart" or "Cause me to respect you sincerely" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: I will praise you with my whole heart
tn.text: Here "heart" represents a person's thoughts, emotions, and motives. AT: "I will praise you completely and sincerely" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "name" represents the whole person. AT: "I will glorify you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: For great is your covenant faithfulness toward me
tn.text: The abstract noun "faithfulness" can be stated as an adjective. AT: "For you are faithful to me because of your covenant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: you have rescued my life from the depths of Sheol
tn.text: This does not mean God brought him back to life after he died. It means God saved him when he was about to die.
This nominal adjective can be stated as an adjective. AT: "arrogant people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
"are coming together to harm me"
This is a way of saying they want to kill him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: abundant in covenant faithfulness and trustworthiness
tn.text: God constantly being faithful and trustworthy is spoken of as if faithfulness and trustworthiness were objects of which God has a large quantity. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Asking God to consider him is spoken of as if he wanted God to turn and look at him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: give your strength to your servant
tn.text: The abstract noun "strength" can be stated as a verb or an adjective. AT: "strengthen your servant" or "make your servant strong" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: your servant ... the son of your servant woman
tn.text: The writer is speaking about himself in the third person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "and they will be ashamed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
